stem: The nurse is preparing to administer eye drops. Place the actions in the correct order.

options.text: Wash hands and don clean gloves.
Instill the prescribed number of drops into the center of the conjunctival sac.
Tilt the client's head back and pull the lower lid down to expose the conjunctival sac.
Instruct the client to close their eye gently.
Apply pressure to the nasolacrimal duct (inner canthus) for 30-60 seconds.

rationale.correct: Proper eye drop technique ensures local absorption and prevents systemic toxicity. (1) Standard precautions. (2) Exposing the sac prevents corneal trauma. (3) Instilling in the center minimizes loss. (4) Gentle closure avoids squeezing the drop out. (5) Punctal occlusion (pressure on the duct) blocks systemic absorption into the bloodstream.
rationale.incorrect: Instilling drops directly onto the cornea is incorrect and painful.
clinicalPearls: If administering multiple eye drops, wait at least 5 minutes between medications to prevent the first drop from being washed out.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember 'Sac, not Eye'. Never drop anything directly on the pupil/cornea.

mnemonic.title: S-L-I-C-C
mnemonic.expansion: Sims (Positioning? No), Lower-Lid, Instill, Close, Canthus.

reviewUnits.heading: Ophthalmic Medication Safety
reviewUnits.body: Nurses monitor for local irritation. When applying ointments, squeeze a thin strip from the inner to the outer canthus.
